Islands in minor-closed classes. I. Bounded treewidth and separators

Zdeněk Dvořák
Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic. E-mail: rakdver@iuuk.mff.cuni.cz. Supported by project 17-04611S (Ramsey-like aspects of graph coloring) of Czech Science Foundation.    Sergey Norin Department of Mathematics and Statistics, McGill University. Email: snorin@math.mcgill.ca. Supported by an NSERC Discovery grant.
Abstract

The clustered chromatic number of a graph class is the minimum integer t𝑡t such that for some C𝐶C the vertices of every graph in the class can be colored in t𝑡t colors so that every monochromatic component has size at most C𝐶C. We show that the clustered chromatic number of the class of graphs embeddable on a given surface is four, proving the conjecture of Esperet and Ochem. Additionally, we study the list version of the concept and characterize the minor-closed classes of graphs of bounded treewidth with given clustered list chromatic number. We further strengthen the above results to solve some extremal problems on bootstrap percolation of minor-closed classes.

1 Introduction

Let G𝐺G and H𝐻H be graphs. A model of H𝐻H in G𝐺G is a function μ𝜇\mu assigning to vertices of H𝐻H pairwise vertex-disjoint non-empty connected subgraphs of G𝐺G such that for every u​v∈E​(H)𝑢𝑣𝐸𝐻uv\in E(H), there exists an edge of G𝐺G with one end in μ​(u)𝜇𝑢\mu(u) and the other end in μ​(v)𝜇𝑣\mu(v). If H𝐻H has a model in G𝐺G, we say that H𝐻H is a minor of G𝐺G, otherwise, we say that G𝐺G is H𝐻H-minor-free. A class 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} of graphs is a (proper) minor-closed class if 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} does not contain all graphs, and for every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} every minor of G𝐺G also belongs to 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. We define the chromatic number χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi(\mathcal{G}) of a graph class G𝐺G as the minimum integer t𝑡t such that every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} is properly t𝑡t-colorable (and χ​(𝒢)=∞𝜒𝒢\chi(\mathcal{G})=\infty if no such t𝑡t exists). The famous Hadwiger’s conjecture can be considered as a characterization of minor-closed graph classes with given chromatic number.

Conjecture 1 (Hadwiger’s conjecture [12]).

Let t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 be an integer, and let 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} be a minor-closed class of graphs. Then χ​(𝒢)≤t𝜒𝒢𝑡\chi(\mathcal{G})\leq t if and only if Kt+1∉𝒢subscript𝐾𝑡1𝒢K_{t+1}\not\in\mathcal{G}.

For integers C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1 and t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, a t𝑡t-coloring with clustering C𝐶C of a graph G𝐺G is a (not necessarily proper) coloring of vertices of G𝐺G using t𝑡t colors such that G𝐺G contains no monochromatic connected subgraph with more than C𝐶C vertices. We denote by χC​(G)subscript𝜒𝐶𝐺\chi_{C}(G) the minimum t𝑡t such that G𝐺G admits a t𝑡t-coloring with clustering C𝐶C. The clustered chromatic number χ⋆​(𝒢)subscript𝜒⋆𝒢\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}) of a graph class 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is the minimum t𝑡t such that there exists C𝐶C so that χC​(G)≤tsubscript𝜒𝐶𝐺𝑡\chi_{C}(G)\leq t for every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} (χ⋆​(𝒢)=∞subscript𝜒⋆𝒢\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G})=\infty if no such t𝑡t exists). The clustered chromatic number of minor-closed classes of graphs has been recently actively investigated, motivated in part by Hadwiger’s conjecture. Let 𝒳​(H)𝒳𝐻\mathcal{X}(H) denote the minor-closed class consisting of all H𝐻H-minor-free graphs. Kawarabayashi and Mohar [15] proved the first linear bound on χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t})) showing that χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))≤⌈31​t2⌉subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡31𝑡2\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))\leq\lceil\frac{31t}{2}\rceil.111No such linear bound is known for χ​(𝒳​(Kt))𝜒𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡\chi(\mathcal{X}(K_{t})). The upper bound on χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t})) has been successively improved in [25, 10, 18]. Most recently, using a beautiful self-contained argument, van den Heuvel and Wood [24] have shown that χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))≤2​t−2subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡2𝑡2\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))\leq 2t-2.

The above definitions can be straightforwardly extended from coloring to list coloring, and many of our techniques extend as well. A t𝑡t-list assignment L𝐿L for a graph G𝐺G assigns a finite set L​(v)𝐿𝑣L(v) of size at least t𝑡t to every vertex v∈V​(G)𝑣𝑉𝐺v\in V(G). An L𝐿L-coloring with clustering C𝐶C of a graph G𝐺G assigns to every vertex v𝑣v a color from L​(v)𝐿𝑣L(v) such that G𝐺G contains no monochromatic connected subgraph with more than C𝐶C vertices. Let χCl​(G)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝐶𝐺\chi^{l}_{C}(G) denote the minimum t𝑡t such that G𝐺G admits an L𝐿L-coloring with clustering C𝐶C for every t𝑡t-list assignment L𝐿L. Clearly, χCl​(G)≥χC​(G)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝐶𝐺subscript𝜒𝐶𝐺\chi^{l}_{C}(G)\geq\chi_{C}(G). The clustered list chromatic number χ⋆l​(𝒢)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢\chi^{l}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}) of a graph class 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is the minimum t𝑡t such that there exists C𝐶C so that χCl​(G)≤tsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝐶𝐺𝑡\chi^{l}_{C}(G)\leq t for every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} (and χ⋆l​(𝒢)=∞subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢\chi^{l}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})=\infty if no such t𝑡t exists).

In the sequel to this paper we show that χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))=χ⋆l​(𝒳​(Kt))=t−1subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡𝑡1\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))=\chi^{l}_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))=t-1, proving the weakening of Hadwiger’s conjecture for clustered chromatic number.222Note that Hadwiger’s conjecture is false for list colorings. In the current paper we introduce two less technical ingredients of the proof, which might be of independent interest. In particular, our results imply the above mentioned bound on χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t})) of van den Heuvel and Wood, using very different techniques.

Rather than working with the clustered (list) chromatic number, we bound a different parameter which dominates it. The coloring number col​(G)col𝐺\text{col}(G) of a graph G𝐺G is the smallest integer t𝑡t such that every non-empty subgraph of G𝐺G contains a vertex of degree less than t𝑡t. A standard greedy argument shows that χ​(G)≤col​(G)𝜒𝐺col𝐺\chi(G)\leq\text{col}(G). Let us now introduce a similar notion for clustered coloring, first defined by Esperet and Ochem [11]. A t𝑡t-island in a graph G𝐺G is a non-empty subset S𝑆S of vertices of G𝐺G such that each vertex of S𝑆S has less than t𝑡t neighbors in V​(G)∖S𝑉𝐺𝑆V(G)\setminus S. Let colC​(G)subscriptcol𝐶𝐺\text{col}_{C}(G) denote the smallest integer t𝑡t such that each non-empty subgraph of G𝐺G contains a t𝑡t-island of size at most C𝐶C. Hence, col1​(G)=col​(G)subscriptcol1𝐺col𝐺\text{col}_{1}(G)=\text{col}(G). The following analogue of the bound χ​(G)≤col​(G)𝜒𝐺col𝐺\chi(G)\leq\text{col}(G) holds for the coloring with bounded clustering.

Lemma 2.

For every integer C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1, every graph G𝐺G satisfies χCl​(G)≤colC​(G)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝐶𝐺subscriptcol𝐶𝐺\chi^{l}_{C}(G)\leq\text{col}_{C}(G).

Proof.

Let L𝐿L be a t𝑡t-list assignment for G𝐺G. Suppose that each non-empty subgraph of G𝐺G contains a t𝑡t-island of size at most C𝐶C. By induction on the size of G𝐺G, we show that G𝐺G has an L𝐿L-coloring with clustering at most C𝐶C. This is trivial if G𝐺G is empty, hence assume that V​(G)≠∅𝑉𝐺V(G)\neq\emptyset. Let S𝑆S be a t𝑡t-island in G𝐺G of size at most C𝐶C. By the induction hypothesis, G−S𝐺𝑆G-S has an L𝐿L-coloring with component size at most C𝐶C. Color each vertex of v∈S𝑣𝑆v\in S by an arbitrary color from L​(v)𝐿𝑣L(v) different from the colors of its neighbors in V​(G)∖S𝑉𝐺𝑆V(G)\setminus S. Clearly, each connected monochromatic subgraph of G𝐺G is contained either in S𝑆S or in V​(G)∖S𝑉𝐺𝑆V(G)\setminus S, and since |S|≤C𝑆𝐶|S|\leq C, we conclude that we obtained an L𝐿L-coloring of G𝐺G with clustering at most C𝐶C. ∎

For a class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} of graphs, let the clustered coloring number col⋆​(𝒢)subscriptcol⋆𝒢\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G}) of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} denote the smallest integer t𝑡t such that there exists C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1 such that colC​(G)≤tsubscriptcol𝐶𝐺𝑡\text{col}_{C}(G)\leq t for every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in{\cal G} (col⋆​(𝒢)=∞subscriptcol⋆𝒢\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})=\infty if no such t𝑡t exists). By Lemma 2, col⋆​(𝒢)≥χ⋆l​(𝒢)≥χ⋆​(𝒢)subscriptcol⋆𝒢subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢subscript𝜒⋆𝒢\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\geq\chi^{l}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\geq\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}), i.e. any upper bound on col⋆​(𝒢)subscriptcol⋆𝒢\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}) gives an upper bound on χ⋆​(𝒢)subscript𝜒⋆𝒢\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}). This observation motivates our investigation of the clustered coloring number in this paper.

It follows from Observation 3 below that col⋆​(𝒳​(Kt+1))≥tsubscriptcol⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡1𝑡\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t+1}))\geq t. On the other hand, for every n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1, there exist minor-closed graph classes 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} containing Knsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n} with col⋆​(𝒢)=1subscriptcol⋆𝒢1\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})=1, e.g., the class of all graphs with at most n𝑛n vertices. Thus the complete minors present in the minor-closed class do not determine the clustered coloring number of the class. This motivates us to ask for an exact description of minor-closed classes 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} with col⋆​(𝒢)≤tsubscriptcol⋆𝒢𝑡\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})\leq t.

Two kinds of graphs seem to play an important role in this context. One of them are the complete bipartite graphs Kn,msubscript𝐾𝑛𝑚K_{n,m}. For the other one, let In+Pmsubscript𝐼𝑛subscript𝑃𝑚I_{n}+P_{m} denote the graph consisting of a path on m𝑚m vertices and n𝑛n additional vertices adjacent to all the vertices of the path. The following is straightforward, and also follows from a stronger Lemma 5 below.

Observation 3.

Let t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 be an integer. For every C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1, there exists m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 such that all t𝑡t-islands in Kt,msubscript𝐾𝑡𝑚K_{t,m} and It−1+Pmsubscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚I_{t-1}+P_{m} have more than C𝐶C vertices.

Thus a class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} with col⋆​(𝒢)≤tsubscriptcol⋆𝒢𝑡\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})\leq t can contain only finitely many graphs of form Kt,msubscript𝐾𝑡𝑚K_{t,m} or It−1+Pmsubscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚I_{t-1}+P_{m}. We conjecture that for minor-closed classes, this condition is also sufficient.

Conjecture 4.

A minor-closed class of graphs 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} satisfies col⋆​(𝒢)≤tsubscriptcol⋆𝒢𝑡\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})\leq t if and only if there exists m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 such that Kt,m∉𝒢subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚𝒢K_{t,m}\not\in{\cal G} and It−1+Pm∉𝒢subscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚𝒢I_{t-1}+P_{m}\not\in{\cal G}.

Conjecture 4 implies that col⋆​(𝒳​(Kt+1))=tsubscriptcol⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡1𝑡\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t+1}))=t (and hence χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt+1))=tsubscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡1𝑡\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t+1}))=t), since Kt+1subscript𝐾𝑡1K_{t+1} is a minor of Kt,msubscript𝐾𝑡𝑚K_{t,m} and It−1+Pmsubscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚I_{t-1}+P_{m} for all m≥t𝑚𝑡m\geq t. In the next section we show that if Conjecture 4 holds, then χ⋆l​(𝒢)=col⋆​(𝒢)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢subscriptcol⋆𝒢\chi^{l}_{\star}({\cal G})=\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G}) for every minor-closed graph class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. On the other hand, the parameters χ⋆subscript𝜒⋆\chi_{\star} and χ⋆lsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆\chi^{l}_{\star} are not tied, and thus, unfortunately, one can not hope to extend the methods of this paper to characterize minor-closed graph classes with given clustered chromatic number. We refer the reader to [21, Conjectures 30 and 32] for a conjectured characterization.

In the next section we state our main results and present several applications, including proofs of two conjectures of Esperet and Ochem. We prove our two main results in Sections 3 and 4.

2 Our results

We start this section by presenting a strengthening of Observation 3 to clustered list chromatic number.

Lemma 5.

For all positive integers C,t𝐶𝑡C,t there exists a positive integer m𝑚m such that χCl​(Kt,m)≥t+1superscriptsubscript𝜒𝐶𝑙subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚𝑡1\chi_{C}^{l}(K_{t,m})\geq t+1 and χCl​(It−1+Pm)≥t+1superscriptsubscript𝜒𝐶𝑙subscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚𝑡1\chi_{C}^{l}(I_{t-1}+P_{m})\geq t+1.

Proof.

We present the proof for G=It−1+Pm𝐺subscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚G=I_{t-1}+P_{m}, the proof for Kt,msubscript𝐾𝑡𝑚K_{t,m} is similar. Since χC​(G)≥2subscript𝜒𝐶𝐺2\chi_{C}(G)\geq 2 for every connected graph G𝐺G with more than C𝐶C vertices, we can assume that t≥2𝑡2t\geq 2. Let S𝑆S be a set of size (t−1)​t𝑡1𝑡(t-1)t. Let L𝐿L be a t𝑡t-list assignment for G𝐺G such that L​(v)⊆S𝐿𝑣𝑆L(v)\subseteq S for all v∈V​(G)𝑣𝑉𝐺v\in V(G) and the vertices of It−1subscript𝐼𝑡1I_{t-1} are assigned disjoint subsets of S𝑆S. Suppose further that for every subset T⊆S𝑇𝑆T\subseteq S with |T|=t𝑇𝑡|T|=t there exists a set QTsubscript𝑄𝑇Q_{T} of t​C2𝑡superscript𝐶2tC^{2} consecutive vertices of Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} such that L​(v)=T𝐿𝑣𝑇L(v)=T for every v∈QT𝑣subscript𝑄𝑇v\in Q_{T}. Clearly such a list assignment exists if m𝑚m is sufficiently large.

Consider an L𝐿L-coloring of G𝐺G. It remains to show that there exists a monochromatic connected subgraph of size more than C𝐶C. Let T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime} be the set of colors assigned to vertices of It−1subscript𝐼𝑡1I_{t-1}. Then |T′|=t−1superscript𝑇′𝑡1|T^{\prime}|=t-1 by the choice of L𝐿L. Let T=T′∪{c}𝑇superscript𝑇′𝑐T=T^{\prime}\cup\{c\} for some color c∈S∖T′𝑐𝑆superscript𝑇′c\in S\setminus T^{\prime}, and let QTsubscript𝑄𝑇Q_{T} be as defined in the previous paragraph. If some color in T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime} is used on at least C𝐶C vertices of QTsubscript𝑄𝑇Q_{T} then G𝐺G contains a monochromatic connected subgraph induced by these vertices and a vertex of It−1subscript𝐼𝑡1I_{t-1}. Otherwise, G𝐺G contains a monochromatic subpath of Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} of length at least (C+1)𝐶1(C+1) induced by the vertices in QTsubscript𝑄𝑇Q_{T} which are colored using color c𝑐c. ∎

Lemma 5 immediately implies the following.

Corollary 6.

Let 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be a class of graphs such that χ⋆l​(𝒢)≤tsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢𝑡\chi^{l}_{\star}({\cal G})\leq t. Then there exists m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 such that Kt,m∉𝒢subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚𝒢K_{t,m}\not\in{\cal G} and It−1+Pm∉𝒢subscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚𝒢I_{t-1}+P_{m}\not\in{\cal G}.

Corollary 6 in particular implies that if Conjecture 4 holds then χ⋆l​(𝒢)=col⋆​(𝒢)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢subscriptcol⋆𝒢\chi^{l}_{\star}({\cal G})=\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G}) for every minor-closed graph class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, as mentioned in the introduction.

Let tw⁡(G)tw𝐺\operatorname{tw}(G) denote the treewidth of the graph G𝐺G.333Treewidth of a graph is defined in Section 4. We say that a class of graphs 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} is of bounded treewidth if there exists an integer w𝑤w such that tw⁡(G)≤wtw𝐺𝑤\operatorname{tw}(G)\leq w for every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in{\cal G}. Our first main result proves Conjecture 4 in the special case of minor-closed classes of graphs of bounded tree-width (or equivalently according to a result of Robertson and Seymour [22], minor-closed classes that do not contain all planar graphs).

Theorem 7.

Let 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be a minor-closed class of graphs of bounded treewidth, and let t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 be an integer. Then col⋆​(𝒢)≤tsubscriptcol⋆𝒢𝑡\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})\leq t if and only if there exists m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 such that Kt,m∉𝒢subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚𝒢K_{t,m}\not\in{\cal G} and It−1+Pm∉𝒢subscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚𝒢I_{t-1}+P_{m}\not\in{\cal G}.

Theorem 7 and Corollary 6 imply the following.

Corollary 8.

If 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} is a minor-closed class of graphs of bounded treewidth, then χ⋆l​(𝒢)=col⋆​(𝒢)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢subscriptcol⋆𝒢\chi^{l}_{\star}({\cal G})=\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G}).

Theorem 7 can be applied to bound the clustered chromatic number of minor-closed classes of unbounded treewidth. The key tool which allows such an application is the following theorem of DeVos et al.

Theorem 9 (DeVos et al. [7]).

For every minor-closed class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} there exists an integer w𝑤w, such that for every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in{\cal G} there exists a partition V1,V2subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2V_{1},V_{2} of V​(G)𝑉𝐺V(G) satisfying tw⁡(G​[V1])≤wtw𝐺delimited-[]subscript𝑉1𝑤\operatorname{tw}(G[V_{1}])\leq w and tw⁡(G​[V2])≤wtw𝐺delimited-[]subscript𝑉2𝑤\operatorname{tw}(G[V_{2}])\leq w.

For ordinary (not list) clustered coloring, one can use disjoint sets of colors on parts V1subscript𝑉1V_{1} and V2subscript𝑉2V_{2} of such a partition. Hence, combining Theorems 7 and 9 and Lemma 2 yields the following.

Corollary 10.

Let 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be a minor-closed class of graphs, and let t,m≥1𝑡𝑚1t,m\geq 1 be integers such that Kt,m∉𝒢subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚𝒢K_{t,m}\not\in{\cal G} and It−1+Pm∉𝒢subscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚𝒢I_{t-1}+P_{m}\not\in{\cal G}. Then χ⋆​(𝒢)≤2​tsubscript𝜒⋆𝒢2𝑡\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\leq 2t.

In particular,

χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt,m))≤2​t+2subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚2𝑡2\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t,m}))\leq 2t+2 (1)

and

χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt+1))≤2​t.subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡12𝑡\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t+1}))\leq 2t. (2)

As mentioned in the introduction, a different proof of the bound (2) is given by van den Heuvel and Wood [24], while (1) improves on the bound χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt,m))≤3​tsubscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚3𝑡\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t,m}))\leq 3t established in [24].

Our second main result bounds the clustered coloring number of minor-closed classes of graphs in terms of the maximum density of the class.

Theorem 11.

For every graph H𝐻H, integer t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and real α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 there exists C>0𝐶0C>0 satisfying the following. Let G𝐺G be an H𝐻H-minor-free graph such that |E​(G)|<(t−α)​|V​(G)|𝐸𝐺𝑡𝛼𝑉𝐺|E(G)|<(t-\alpha)|V(G)|. Then G𝐺G contains a t𝑡t-island of size at most C𝐶C.

Theorem 11 immediately implies the following.

Corollary 12.

Let 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be a class of graphs closed under taking subgraphs, such that 𝒢⊆𝒳​(H)𝒢𝒳𝐻{\cal G}\subseteq\mathcal{X}(H) for some graph H𝐻H. Let real d>0𝑑0d>0 be such that |E​(G)|≤d​|V​(G)|+o​(|V​(G)|)𝐸𝐺𝑑𝑉𝐺𝑜𝑉𝐺|E(G)|\leq d|V(G)|+o(|V(G)|) for all graphs G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in{\cal G}. Then col⋆​(𝒢)≤⌊d+1⌋subscriptcol⋆𝒢𝑑1\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\leq\lfloor d+1\rfloor.

For a surface ΣΣ\Sigma let 𝒢​(Σ)𝒢Σ\mathcal{G}(\Sigma) denote the (minor-closed) class of graphs embeddable on ΣΣ\Sigma. Kleinberg, Motwani, Raghavan, and Venkatasubramanian [16] and, independently, Alon, Ding, Oporowski and Vertigan [1] proved that χ⋆​(𝒢​(Σ))≥4subscript𝜒⋆𝒢Σ4\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma))\geq 4 for every surface ΣΣ\Sigma. Thus col⋆​(𝒢​(Σ))≥4subscriptcol⋆𝒢Σ4\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma))\geq 4. By Euler’s formula, for every surface ΣΣ\Sigma there exists a constant c​(Σ)𝑐Σc(\Sigma) such that |E​(G)|≤3​|V​(G)|+c​(Σ)𝐸𝐺3𝑉𝐺𝑐Σ|E(G)|\leq 3|V(G)|+c(\Sigma) for all graphs G∈𝒢​(Σ)𝐺𝒢ΣG\in{\cal G}(\Sigma). Thus Corollary 12 implies that the above lower bounds on col⋆​(𝒢​(Σ))subscriptcol⋆𝒢Σ\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma)) and χ⋆​(𝒢​(Σ))≥4subscript𝜒⋆𝒢Σ4\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma))\geq 4 are tight, as conjectured by Esperet and Ochem [11, Conjecture 3].

Corollary 13.

For every surface ΣΣ\Sigma

χ⋆​(𝒢​(Σ))=χ⋆l​(𝒢​(Σ))=col⋆​(𝒢​(Σ))=4.subscript𝜒⋆𝒢Σsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢Σsubscriptcol⋆𝒢Σ4\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma))=\chi^{l}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma))=\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma))=4.

Let 𝒢5​(Σ)subscript𝒢5Σ\mathcal{G}_{5}(\Sigma) be the class of graphs with girth at least five which are embeddable on ΣΣ\Sigma. The question of determining χ⋆​(𝒢5​(ℝ2))subscript𝜒⋆subscript𝒢5superscriptℝ2\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}_{5}(\mathbb{R}^{2})) was considered, in particular, in [3], and was until now open. Euler’s formula again gives us a density bound |E​(G)|≤5/3​|V​(G)|+c​(Σ)𝐸𝐺53𝑉𝐺𝑐Σ|E(G)|\leq 5/3|V(G)|+c(\Sigma) for some c​(Σ)𝑐Σc(\Sigma) and all G∈𝒢5​(Σ)𝐺subscript𝒢5ΣG\in\mathcal{G}_{5}(\Sigma), and thus Corollary 12 implies the following bound on col⋆​(𝒢​(Σ))subscriptcol⋆𝒢Σ\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}(\Sigma)) conjectured in [11, Conjecture 7].

Corollary 14.

For every surface ΣΣ\Sigma

χ⋆​(𝒢5​(Σ))=χ⋆l​(𝒢5​(Σ))=col⋆​(𝒢5​(Σ))=2.subscript𝜒⋆subscript𝒢5Σsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆subscript𝒢5Σsubscriptcol⋆subscript𝒢5Σ2\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{G}_{5}(\Sigma))=\chi^{l}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}_{5}(\Sigma))=\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}_{5}(\Sigma))=2.

Corollary 12 can also be used to determine col⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))subscriptcol⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t})) for t≤9𝑡9t\leq 9. By the results of  [8, 13, 19, 23] if G𝐺G is a Ktsubscript𝐾𝑡K_{t}-minor free graph for some t≤9𝑡9t\leq 9 then |E​(G)|≤(t−2)​|V​(G)|𝐸𝐺𝑡2𝑉𝐺|E(G)|\leq(t-2)|V(G)|. This implies the following.

Corollary 15.

Let 1≤t≤91𝑡91\leq t\leq 9 be an integer. Then

χ⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))=χ⋆l​(𝒳​(Kt))=col⋆​(𝒳​(Kt))=t−1.subscript𝜒⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡subscriptcol⋆𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡𝑡1\chi_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))=\chi^{l}_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))=\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))=t-1.

Finally, let us discuss a relationship to another concept, bootstrap percolation. Consider the following process on a graph G𝐺G for some integer t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0. Let vertices of some set A0⊆V​(G)subscript𝐴0𝑉𝐺A_{0}\subseteq V(G) be marked active. If there exists an inactive vertex v𝑣v in G𝐺G with at least t𝑡t active neighbors, v𝑣v becomes active. We repeat this procedure until there are no more inactive vertices with at least t𝑡t active neighbors. If at the end, all vertices of G𝐺G are active, we say that the set A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} t𝑡t-percolates. Bootstrap percolation was introduced by Chalupa, Leath and Reich [5] as a simplification of existing models of ferromagnetism. Extremal problems for bootstrap percolation, similar to the ones we consider in this paper, were studied for very structured graph families e.g. in [4, 20].

For ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, we say that a graph G𝐺G is ε𝜀\varepsilon-resistant to t𝑡t-percolation if no set of at most ε​|V​(G)|𝜀𝑉𝐺\varepsilon|V(G)| vertices of G𝐺G t𝑡t-percolates. For a class of graphs 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, let us define the percolation threshold p​(𝒢)𝑝𝒢p({\cal G}) of 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} to be the minimum integer t𝑡t such that for some ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, all non-null graphs in 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} are ε𝜀\varepsilon-resistant to t𝑡t-percolation (p​(𝒢)=∞𝑝𝒢p({\cal G})=\infty if no such t𝑡t exists). Clearly, all graphs in 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} are also ε𝜀\varepsilon-resistant to t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}-percolation for every t′≥tsuperscript𝑡′𝑡t^{\prime}\geq t.

How to show that a class is percolation resistant? Observe that a set t𝑡t-percolates if and only if no t𝑡t-island is contained in its complement. If a graph G𝐺G contains more than ε​|V​(G)|𝜀𝑉𝐺\varepsilon|V(G)| pairwise disjoint t𝑡t-islands, then each set of size at most ε​|V​(G)|𝜀𝑉𝐺\varepsilon|V(G)| is disjoint from at least one of them, and thus it does not t𝑡t-percolate. Hence, the following notion gives an upper bound to the percolation threshold. Let the pervasive clustered coloring number pcol⋆​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G}) denote the minimum integer t𝑡t such that for some ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, each graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in{\cal G} contains at least ε​|V​(G)|𝜀𝑉𝐺\varepsilon|V(G)| pairwise disjoint t𝑡t-islands (pcol⋆​(𝒢)=∞subscriptpcol⋆𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})=\infty if no such t𝑡t exists).

If G𝐺G contains linearly many pairwise disjoint t𝑡t-islands, some of them must have constant size. Hence, for a subgraph-closed class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} we have inequalities pcol⋆​(𝒢)≥p​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑝𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})\geq p({\cal G}) and pcol⋆​(𝒢)≥col⋆​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢subscriptcol⋆𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})\geq\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G}). In general, percolation threshold may be smaller than the clustered coloring number; e.g., for t≥3𝑡3t\geq 3 the class of graphs G𝐺G with maximum degree at most t𝑡t and girth Ω​(log⁡(|V​(G)|))Ω𝑉𝐺\Omega(\log(|V(G)|)) has clustered coloring number t𝑡t (since in t𝑡t-regular graphs in the class, all (t−1)𝑡1(t-1)-islands must contain cycles) but all the graphs in this class are (t−2)/(2​t−2)𝑡22𝑡2(t-2)/(2t-2)-resistant to (t−1)𝑡1(t-1)-percolation (since the complements of sets of size at most t−22​t−2​|V​(G)|𝑡22𝑡2𝑉𝐺\tfrac{t-2}{2t-2}|V(G)| contain a vertex of degree at most t−2𝑡2t-2, or two vertices of degree t−1𝑡1t-1 joined by a path, or a cycle, forming a (t−1)𝑡1(t-1)-island).

However, in Section 3 we prove the following.

Theorem 16.

Let 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be a class of graphs closed under taking subgraphs, such that 𝒢⊆𝒳​(H)𝒢𝒳𝐻{\cal G}\subseteq\mathcal{X}(H) for some graph H𝐻H. Then pcol⋆​(𝒢)=p​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑝𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})=p({\cal G}).

Hence for the minor closed classes percolation threshold bounds the clustered coloring number. Rather than proving Theorems 7 and 11 directly, we bound the percolation threshold and the pervasive clustered coloring number of the corresponding graph classes, proving the following strengthening of Theorems 7 and 11, respectively.

Theorem 17.

Let 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be a minor-closed class. If 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} has bounded treewidth, then pcol⋆​(𝒢)=p​(𝒢)=col⋆​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑝𝒢subscriptcol⋆𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})=p({\cal G})=\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G}) is equal to the smallest integer t𝑡t such that for some m≥0𝑚0m\geq 0 neither Kt,msubscript𝐾𝑡𝑚K_{t,m} nor It−1+Pmsubscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚I_{t-1}+P_{m} belongs to 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}.

Theorem 18.

For every graph H𝐻H, integer t>0𝑡0t>0 and α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 there exists δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 satisfying the following. Let G𝐺G be an H𝐻H-minor-free graph satisfying |E​(G)|≤(t−α)​|V​(G)|𝐸𝐺𝑡𝛼𝑉𝐺|E(G)|\leq(t-\alpha)|V(G)|. Then G𝐺G contains at least δ​|V​(G)|𝛿𝑉𝐺\delta|V(G)| disjoint t𝑡t-islands.

Note that Theorem 18 implies the following strengthening of Corollary 12.

Corollary 19.

Let 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be a class of graphs closed under taking subgraphs, such that 𝒢⊆𝒳​(H)𝒢𝒳𝐻{\cal G}\subseteq\mathcal{X}(H) for some graph H𝐻H. Let real d>0𝑑0d>0 be such that |E​(G)|≤d​|V​(G)|+o​(|V​(G)|)𝐸𝐺𝑑𝑉𝐺𝑜𝑉𝐺|E(G)|\leq d|V(G)|+o(|V(G)|) for all graphs G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in{\cal G}. Then pcol⋆​(𝒢)≤⌊d+1⌋subscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑑1\text{pcol}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\leq\lfloor d+1\rfloor.

We prove Theorems 16 and 18 (and thus Theorem 11) in Section 3, and we prove Theorem 17 (and thus Theorem 7) in Section  4.

3 Percolation and clustered coloring in classes with sublinear separators

In this section we prove Theorems 16 and 18. In fact we show that these results hold not just for minor-closed classes, but for a wider family of graph classes which admit “good” separators. We start by defining this family.

A separation of a graph G𝐺G is a pair (L,R)𝐿𝑅(L,R) of its subgraphs such that G=L∪R𝐺𝐿𝑅G=L\cup R; note that V​(L∩R)𝑉𝐿𝑅V(L\cap R) is a vertex-cut in G𝐺G separating V​(L)∖V​(R)𝑉𝐿𝑉𝑅V(L)\setminus V(R) from V​(R)∖V​(L)𝑉𝑅𝑉𝐿V(R)\setminus V(L), if these two sets are non-empty. Let f:ℕ→ℕ:𝑓→ℕℕf:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N} be a non-decreasing function. We say that a class of graphs 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} has f𝑓f-separators, if for every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} there exists a separation (L,R)𝐿𝑅(L,R) of G𝐺G of order at most f​(|V​(G)|)𝑓𝑉𝐺f(|V(G)|) such that |V​(L)∖V​(R)|,|V​(R)∖V​(L)|≤23​|V​(H)|𝑉𝐿𝑉𝑅𝑉𝑅𝑉𝐿23𝑉𝐻|V(L)\setminus V(R)|,|V(R)\setminus V(L)|\leq\frac{2}{3}|V(H)|. We say that a function f𝑓f is significantly sublinear if the sum

∑i≥0f​((3/2)i)(3/2)isubscript𝑖0𝑓superscript32𝑖superscript32𝑖\sum_{i\geq 0}\frac{f((3/2)^{i})}{(3/2)^{i}}

is finite444Note that this is the case for example if f​(n)=n/g​(n)𝑓𝑛𝑛𝑔𝑛f(n)=n/g(n) for some function g​(n)=Ω​(log1+ε⁡n)𝑔𝑛Ωsuperscript1𝜀𝑛g(n)=\Omega(\log^{1+\varepsilon}n) with ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0.. We use an argument of Lipton and Tarjan [17] to prove the following.

Lemma 20.

Let f:ℕ→ℕ:𝑓→ℕℕf:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N} be a non-decreasing significantly sublinear function. Let 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} be a class of graphs closed under taking subgraphs that has f𝑓f-separators. For every ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 there exists C𝐶C as follows. For every n𝑛n-vertex graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} there exists X⊆V​(G)𝑋𝑉𝐺X\subseteq V(G) such that |X|≤ε​n𝑋𝜀𝑛|X|\leq\varepsilon n and every component of G−X𝐺𝑋G-X has at most C𝐶C vertices.

Proof.

Since f𝑓f is significantly sublinear, there exists i0subscript𝑖0i_{0} such that

∑i≥i0f​((3/2)i)(3/2)i≤23​ε.subscript𝑖subscript𝑖0𝑓superscript32𝑖superscript32𝑖23𝜀\sum_{i\geq i_{0}}\frac{f((3/2)^{i})}{(3/2)^{i}}\leq\frac{2}{3}\varepsilon.

Let C=⌈(3/2)i0⌉𝐶superscript32subscript𝑖0C=\lceil(3/2)^{i_{0}}\rceil.

Without loss of generality, we can assume that G𝐺G is connected, as otherwise we can find the set X𝑋X separately in each component. Let us define a rooted tree T𝑇T and a mapping θ𝜃\theta of its vertices to connected induced subgraphs of G𝐺G as follows. For the root r𝑟r of T𝑇T, we set θ​(r)=G𝜃𝑟𝐺\theta(r)=G. For any v∈V​(G)𝑣𝑉𝐺v\in V(G), if |V​(θ​(v))|≤C𝑉𝜃𝑣𝐶|V(\theta(v))|\leq C, then v𝑣v is a leaf of T𝑇T. Otherwise, let (Lv,Rv)subscript𝐿𝑣subscript𝑅𝑣(L_{v},R_{v}) be a separation of θ​(v)𝜃𝑣\theta(v) order at most f​(|V​(θ​(v))|)𝑓𝑉𝜃𝑣f(|V(\theta(v))|) and let Xv=Lv∩Rvsubscript𝑋𝑣subscript𝐿𝑣subscript𝑅𝑣X_{v}=L_{v}\cap R_{v}. If H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}, …, Hksubscript𝐻𝑘H_{k} are the components of θ​(v)−Xv𝜃𝑣subscript𝑋𝑣\theta(v)-X_{v}, then v𝑣v has k𝑘k children v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}, …, vksubscript𝑣𝑘v_{k} in T𝑇T with θ​(vi)=Hi𝜃subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝐻𝑖\theta(v_{i})=H_{i} for i=1,…,k𝑖1…𝑘i=1,\ldots,k.

We let X𝑋X be the union of the sets Xvsubscript𝑋𝑣X_{v} over all non-leaf vertices v𝑣v of T𝑇T. By the construction of T𝑇T, every component of G−X𝐺𝑋G-X has at most C𝐶C vertices, and thus it suffices to bound the size of X𝑋X. For v∈V​(T)𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V(T), define 𝚛𝚊𝚗𝚔​(v)=⌊log3/2⁡|V​(θ​(v))|⌋𝚛𝚊𝚗𝚔𝑣subscript32𝑉𝜃𝑣\mathtt{rank}(v)=\lfloor\log_{3/2}|V(\theta(v))|\rfloor. Observe that the rank is decreasing on each path in T𝑇T starting in the root, and in particular, if 𝚛𝚊𝚗𝚔​(u)=𝚛𝚊𝚗𝚔​(v)𝚛𝚊𝚗𝚔𝑢𝚛𝚊𝚗𝚔𝑣\mathtt{rank}(u)=\mathtt{rank}(v) for distinct u,v∈V​(T)𝑢𝑣𝑉𝑇u,v\in V(T), then θ​(u)𝜃𝑢\theta(u) and θ​(v)𝜃𝑣\theta(v) are vertex-disjoint. For any i≥⌊log3/2⁡C⌋𝑖subscript32𝐶i\geq\lfloor\log_{3/2}C\rfloor, let Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} be the set of non-leaf vertices v𝑣v of T𝑇T of rank i𝑖i and let Xi=⋃v∈ViXvsubscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑣subscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑋𝑣X_{i}=\bigcup_{v\in V_{i}}X_{v}. Since (3/2)i≤|V​(θ​(v))|<(3/2)i+1superscript32𝑖𝑉𝜃𝑣superscript32𝑖1(3/2)^{i}\leq|V(\theta(v))|<(3/2)^{i+1} for all v∈Vi𝑣subscript𝑉𝑖v\in V_{i}, we have |Vi|≤n/(3/2)isubscript𝑉𝑖𝑛superscript32𝑖|V_{i}|\leq n/(3/2)^{i} and |Xv|≤f​((3/2)i+1)subscript𝑋𝑣𝑓superscript32𝑖1|X_{v}|\leq f((3/2)^{i+1}), and thus |Xi|≤f​((3/2)i+1)(3/2)i​nsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑓superscript32𝑖1superscript32𝑖𝑛|X_{i}|\leq\frac{f((3/2)^{i+1})}{(3/2)^{i}}n. Consequently,

|X|≤∑i≥⌊log3/2⁡C⌋|Xi|≤n⋅32​∑i≥⌊log3/2⁡C⌋+1f​((3/2)i)(3/2)i≤ε​n,𝑋subscript𝑖subscript32𝐶subscript𝑋𝑖⋅𝑛32subscript𝑖subscript32𝐶1𝑓superscript32𝑖superscript32𝑖𝜀𝑛|X|\leq\sum_{i\geq\lfloor\log_{3/2}C\rfloor}|X_{i}|\leq n\cdot\frac{3}{2}\sum_{i\geq\lfloor\log_{3/2}C\rfloor+1}\frac{f((3/2)^{i})}{(3/2)^{i}}\leq\varepsilon n,

as required. ∎

In order to prove a strengthening of Theorem 18, we need one more definition. For a subset A⊆V​(G)𝐴𝑉𝐺A\subseteq V(G), let eG​(A)subscript𝑒𝐺𝐴e_{G}(A) (or e​(A)𝑒𝐴e(A) for ease of notation when the graph G𝐺G is clear from the context) denote the number of edges of G𝐺G with at least one end in A𝐴A. We say that A⊆V​(G)𝐴𝑉𝐺A\subseteq V(G) is a t𝑡t-enclave if eG​(A)<t​|A|subscript𝑒𝐺𝐴𝑡𝐴e_{G}(A)<t|A|. The following observation is easy, but useful.

Lemma 21.

Let G𝐺G be a graph, and let A𝐴A be a t𝑡t-enclave in G𝐺G. Then there exists a t𝑡t-island S⊆A𝑆𝐴S\subseteq A in G𝐺G.

Proof.

Choose a minimal t𝑡t-enclave S⊆A𝑆𝐴S\subseteq A. Note that S≠∅𝑆S\neq\emptyset, since 0≤e​(S)<t​|S|0𝑒𝑆𝑡𝑆0\leq e(S)<t|S|. We claim that S𝑆S is an island, as desired. Suppose for a contradiction that there exists v∈S𝑣𝑆v\in S with at least t𝑡t neighbors in V​(G)−S𝑉𝐺𝑆V(G)-S. Then

e​(S∖v)≤e​(S)−t​<t|​S|−t=t​|S∖v|.𝑒𝑆𝑣𝑒𝑆conditional𝑡bra𝑡𝑆𝑡𝑡𝑆𝑣e(S\setminus v)\leq e(S)-t<t|S|-t=t|S\setminus v|.

Thus S∖v𝑆𝑣S\setminus v is a t𝑡t-enclave, contradicting the choice of S𝑆S. ∎

Alon, Seymour and Thomas [2] proved that any minor-closed class of graphs 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} has f𝑓f-separators for f​(n)=O​(n1/2)𝑓𝑛𝑂superscript𝑛12f(n)=O(n^{1/2}), which is significantly sublinear. Therefore the next result implies Theorem 18.

Theorem 22.

Let f:ℕ→ℕ:𝑓→ℕℕf:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N} be a non-decreasing significantly sublinear function. Let 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} be a class of graphs closed under taking subgraphs that has f𝑓f-separators. For every integer t>0𝑡0t>0 and α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 there exists δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 so that every G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} satisfying |E​(G)|≤(t−α)​|V​(G)|𝐸𝐺𝑡𝛼𝑉𝐺|E(G)|\leq(t-\alpha)|V(G)| contains at least δ​|V​(G)|𝛿𝑉𝐺\delta|V(G)| disjoint t𝑡t-islands.

Proof.

Let ε=α2​t𝜀𝛼2𝑡\varepsilon=\frac{\alpha}{2t}. Let C𝐶C be chosen to satisfy the conclusion of Lemma 20 for this ε𝜀\varepsilon and 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, and let δ=α2​t​C𝛿𝛼2𝑡𝐶\delta=\frac{\alpha}{2tC}. Consider an n𝑛n-vertex graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} satisfying |E​(G)|≤(t−α)​n𝐸𝐺𝑡𝛼𝑛|E(G)|\leq(t-\alpha)n. By the choice of C𝐶C there exists a set X⊆V​(G)𝑋𝑉𝐺X\subseteq V(G) of size at most ε​n𝜀𝑛\varepsilon n such that every component of G−X𝐺𝑋G-X has at most C𝐶C vertices. Let 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} be the collection of vertex sets of the components of G−X𝐺𝑋G-X, let 𝒦′superscript𝒦′\mathcal{K}^{\prime} be the collection of the sets in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} which are t𝑡t-enclaves, and let 𝒦′′=𝒦−𝒦′superscript𝒦′′𝒦superscript𝒦′\mathcal{K}^{\prime\prime}=\mathcal{K}-\mathcal{K}^{\prime}. By Lemma 21 it suffices to show that |𝒦′|≥δ​nsuperscript𝒦′𝛿𝑛|\mathcal{K}^{\prime}|\geq\delta n. If not, then

∑K∈𝒦′′|K|=n−|X|−∑K∈𝒦′|K|>(1−ε−δ​C)​n=(1−αt)​n.subscript𝐾superscript𝒦′′𝐾𝑛𝑋subscript𝐾superscript𝒦′𝐾1𝜀𝛿𝐶𝑛1𝛼𝑡𝑛\sum_{K\in\mathcal{K}^{\prime\prime}}|K|=n-|X|-\sum_{K\in\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}|K|>(1-\varepsilon-\delta C)n=\left(1-\frac{\alpha}{t}\right)n.

Moreover, we have e​(K)≥t​|K|𝑒𝐾𝑡𝐾e(K)\geq t|K| for every K∈𝒦′′𝐾superscript𝒦′′K\in\mathcal{K}^{\prime\prime}, and thus

|E​(G)|≥∑K∈𝒦′′e​(K)≥t​∑K∈𝒦′′|K|>t​(1−αt)​n=(t−α)​n,𝐸𝐺subscript𝐾superscript𝒦′′𝑒𝐾𝑡subscript𝐾superscript𝒦′′𝐾𝑡1𝛼𝑡𝑛𝑡𝛼𝑛\displaystyle|E(G)|\geq\sum_{K\in\mathcal{K^{\prime\prime}}}e(K)\geq t\sum_{K\in\mathcal{K^{\prime\prime}}}|K|>t\left(1-\frac{\alpha}{t}\right)n=(t-\alpha)n,

which contradicts the assumption of the theorem. ∎

Let us remark that the argument of Theorem 22 also directly implies Theorem 11, since all the t𝑡t-enclaves we obtain have bounded size (it is possible to simplify the proof a bit in this weakened case, since we only need to prove the existence of one such t𝑡t-enclave).

The following result with an analogous proof implies Theorem 16.

Theorem 23.

Let f:ℕ→ℕ:𝑓→ℕℕf:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N} be a non-decreasing significantly sublinear function. Let 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} be a class of graphs closed under taking subgraphs that has f𝑓f-separators. Then p​(𝒢)=pcol⋆​(𝒢)𝑝𝒢subscriptpcol⋆𝒢p(\mathcal{G})=\text{pcol}_{\star}(\mathcal{G}).

Proof.

Since pcol⋆​(𝒢)≥p​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑝𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\geq p(\mathcal{G}) in general, it suffices to show that pcol⋆​(𝒢)≤p​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑝𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\leq p(\mathcal{G}). Letting t=p​(𝒢)𝑡𝑝𝒢t=p(\mathcal{G}), there exists ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 such that 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is 2​ε2𝜀2\varepsilon-resistant to t𝑡t-percolation. Let C𝐶C be chosen to satisfy the conclusion of Lemma 20 for ε𝜀\varepsilon and 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. We claim that every graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} contains at least εC​|V​(G)|𝜀𝐶𝑉𝐺\frac{\varepsilon}{C}|V(G)| disjoint t𝑡t-islands. The claim implies that pcol⋆​(𝒢)≤tsubscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑡\text{pcol}_{\star}(\mathcal{G})\leq t, and hence the theorem.

It remains to establish the claim. Let G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} be an n𝑛n-vertex graph. By the choice of C𝐶C, there exists X⊆V​(G)𝑋𝑉𝐺X\subseteq V(G) such that |X|≤ε​n𝑋𝜀𝑛|X|\leq\varepsilon n and every component of G−X𝐺𝑋G-X has at most C𝐶C vertices. Let 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} be the set of all components K𝐾K of G−X𝐺𝑋G-X such that there exists a t𝑡t-island S⊆V​(K)𝑆𝑉𝐾S\subseteq V(K) in G𝐺G. It suffices to show that |𝒦|≥εC​n𝒦𝜀𝐶𝑛|\mathcal{K}|\geq\frac{\varepsilon}{C}n. If not, then the set Z=X∪⋃K∈𝒦V​(K)𝑍𝑋subscript𝐾𝒦𝑉𝐾Z=X\cup\bigcup_{K\in\mathcal{K}}V(K) has size at most ε​n+C​|𝒦|≤2​ε​n𝜀𝑛𝐶𝒦2𝜀𝑛\varepsilon n+C|\mathcal{K}|\leq 2\varepsilon n. By the choice of ε𝜀\varepsilon there exists a t𝑡t-island S⊆V​(G)−V​(Z)𝑆𝑉𝐺𝑉𝑍S\subseteq V(G)-V(Z). Choose such S𝑆S to be minimal, then G​[S]𝐺delimited-[]𝑆G[S] is connected, and so S⊆V​(K)𝑆𝑉𝐾S\subseteq V(K) for some component K𝐾K of G−X𝐺𝑋G-X. However, K∉𝒦𝐾𝒦K\not\in\mathcal{K} by the choice of Z𝑍Z. This contradiction finishes the proof. ∎

4 Clustered chromatic number of classes of bounded treewidth

We start by introducing the necessary concepts. For sets A,B𝐴𝐵A,B of vertices of a graph of the same size k𝑘k, an A−B𝐴𝐵A-B linkage is a set of k𝑘k pairwise vertex-disjoint paths with one end in A𝐴A and the other end in B𝐵B.

Let G𝐺G and H𝐻H be graphs. An H𝐻H-decomposition of G𝐺G is a function β𝛽\beta that to each vertex z𝑧z of H𝐻H assigns a subset of vertices of G𝐺G (called the bag of z𝑧z), such that for every u​v∈E​(G)𝑢𝑣𝐸𝐺uv\in E(G), there exists z∈V​(H)𝑧𝑉𝐻z\in V(H) with {u,v}⊆β​(z)𝑢𝑣𝛽𝑧\{u,v\}\subseteq\beta(z), and for every v∈V​(G)𝑣𝑉𝐺v\in V(G), the set {z:v∈β​(z)}conditional-set𝑧𝑣𝛽𝑧\{z:v\in\beta(z)\} induces a non-empty connected subgraph of H𝐻H. When H𝐻H is a path or a tree, we say that (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) is a path or tree decomposition of G𝐺G, respectively. The width of an H𝐻H-decomposition is defined as max⁡{|β​(x)|:x∈V​(H)}−1:𝛽𝑥𝑥𝑉𝐻1\max\{|\beta(x)|:x\in V(H)\}-1, and the adhesion of an H𝐻H-decomposition is max⁡{|β​(x)∩β​(y)|:x​y∈E​(H)}:𝛽𝑥𝛽𝑦𝑥𝑦𝐸𝐻\max\{|\beta(x)\cap\beta(y)|:xy\in E(H)\}. The treewidth tw⁡(G)tw𝐺\operatorname{tw}(G) of a graph G𝐺G is the minimum width of a tree decomposition of G𝐺G.

A path decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) is linked if for every z∈V​(H)𝑧𝑉𝐻z\in V(H) with two neighbors x𝑥x and y𝑦y, there exists a (β​(z)∩β​(x))−(β​(z)∩β​(y))𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑥𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑦(\beta(z)\cap\beta(x))-(\beta(z)\cap\beta(y)) linkage in G​[β​(z)]𝐺delimited-[]𝛽𝑧G[\beta(z)] (and in particular, all the intersections of adjacent bags have the same size). Conversely, if |β​(z)∩β​(x)|=|β​(z)∩β​(y)|=p𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑥𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑦𝑝|\beta(z)\cap\beta(x)|=|\beta(z)\cap\beta(y)|=p and there exists a separation (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B) of G​[β​(z)]𝐺delimited-[]𝛽𝑧G[\beta(z)] of order less than p𝑝p with β​(z)∩β​(x)⊆V​(A)𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑥𝑉𝐴\beta(z)\cap\beta(x)\subseteq V(A) and β​(z)∩β​(y)⊆V​(B)𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑦𝑉𝐵\beta(z)\cap\beta(y)\subseteq V(B), we say that z𝑧z has broken bag; by Menger’s theorem, a path decomposition such that all the intersections of adjacent bags have the same size is linked if and only if it does not contain a broken bag. An H𝐻H-decomposition is proper if β​(x)⊈β​(y)not-subset-of-or-equals𝛽𝑥𝛽𝑦\beta(x)\not\subseteq\beta(y) for every x​y∈E​(H)𝑥𝑦𝐸𝐻xy\in E(H). The order of an H𝐻H-decomposition is |V​(H)|𝑉𝐻|V(H)|. For a path decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta), a path decomposition (H′,β′)superscript𝐻′superscript𝛽′(H^{\prime},\beta^{\prime}) is a coarsening of (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) if there exists a model μ𝜇\mu of H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime} in H𝐻H such that ⋃z∈V​(H′)V​(μ​(z))=V​(H)subscript𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′𝑉𝜇𝑧𝑉𝐻\bigcup_{z\in V(H^{\prime})}V(\mu(z))=V(H) and β′​(z)=⋃x∈V​(μ​(z))β​(x)superscript𝛽′𝑧subscript𝑥𝑉𝜇𝑧𝛽𝑥\beta^{\prime}(z)=\bigcup_{x\in V(\mu(z))}\beta(x) for all z∈V​(H′)𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′z\in V(H^{\prime}). A path decomposition of G𝐺G is appearance-universal if every vertex v∈V​(G)𝑣𝑉𝐺v\in V(G) either appears in all bags of the decomposition, or in at most two (consecutive) bags. A vertex v𝑣v is internal if it appears in only one bag. A path decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) has large interiors if for every z∈V​(H)𝑧𝑉𝐻z\in V(H) with two neighbors x𝑥x and y𝑦y, there exists an internal vertex contained in β​(z)𝛽𝑧\beta(z) and no internal vertex has a neighbor both in β​(x)∖β​(y)𝛽𝑥𝛽𝑦\beta(x)\setminus\beta(y) and in β​(y)∖β​(x)𝛽𝑦𝛽𝑥\beta(y)\setminus\beta(x).

We now show how to transform a tree decomposition of large order and bounded width into a path decomposition of large order and bounded adhesion, and then to clean it up, making it linked, appearance-universal, and with large interiors. The techniques to do so are standard and appear e.g. in [14]; we give brief arguments here to adjust for minor technical details and notational differences.

Observation 24.

A coarsening of a proper decomposition is proper. A coarsening of a linked decomposition is linked. A coarsening of a decomposition of adhesion p𝑝p has adhesion at most p𝑝p. A coarsening of an appearance-universal decomposition is appearance-universal; furthermore, if an appearance-universal decomposition has large interiors, then its coarsening has large interiors.

Lemma 25.

Let k,n≥1𝑘𝑛1k,n\geq 1 be integers. If a graph G𝐺G has a proper tree decomposition (T,β)𝑇𝛽(T,\beta) of order at least nnsuperscript𝑛𝑛n^{n} with bags of size at most k𝑘k, then G𝐺G has a proper path decomposition of adhesion at most k𝑘k and order at least n𝑛n.

Proof.

If T𝑇T has a vertex z𝑧z of degree m≥n𝑚𝑛m\geq n, then let T1subscript𝑇1T_{1}, …, Tmsubscript𝑇𝑚T_{m} be the components of T−z𝑇𝑧T-z, let H𝐻H be a path z1​z2​…​zmsubscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2…subscript𝑧𝑚z_{1}z_{2}\ldots z_{m} and let γ​(zi)=β​(z)∪⋃x∈V​(Ti)β​(x)𝛾subscript𝑧𝑖𝛽𝑧subscript𝑥𝑉subscript𝑇𝑖𝛽𝑥\gamma(z_{i})=\beta(z)\cup\bigcup_{x\in V(T_{i})}\beta(x). Otherwise, T𝑇T contains a subpath H𝐻H with at least n𝑛n vertices; for z∈V​(H)𝑧𝑉𝐻z\in V(H), let Tzsubscript𝑇𝑧T_{z} be the component of T−(V​(H)∖{z})𝑇𝑉𝐻𝑧T-(V(H)\setminus\{z\}) containing z𝑧z, and let γ​(z)=⋃x∈V​(Tz)β​(x)𝛾𝑧subscript𝑥𝑉subscript𝑇𝑧𝛽𝑥\gamma(z)=\bigcup_{x\in V(T_{z})}\beta(x). In both cases, (H,γ)𝐻𝛾(H,\gamma) is a proper path decomposition of G𝐺G of adhesion at most k𝑘k. ∎

Lemma 26.

There exists a function flink:Z0+×Z+→Z+:subscript𝑓link→subscriptsuperscript𝑍0superscript𝑍superscript𝑍f_{\text{link}}:Z^{+}_{0}\times Z^{+}\to Z^{+} as follows. Let p𝑝p and n𝑛n be integers. If G𝐺G has a proper path decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) with adhesion at most p𝑝p of order at least flink​(p,n)subscript𝑓link𝑝𝑛f_{\text{link}}(p,n), then G𝐺G has a proper linked path decomposition of adhesion at most p𝑝p and order n𝑛n.

Proof.

Choose flinksubscript𝑓linkf_{\text{link}} so that flink​(0,n)=nsubscript𝑓link0𝑛𝑛f_{\text{link}}(0,n)=n and flink​(p,n)=flink​(p−1,n)+(flink​(p−1,n)−2)​(n−1)−1subscript𝑓link𝑝𝑛subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛2𝑛11f_{\text{link}}(p,n)=f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n)+(f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n)-2)(n-1)-1 for every p,n≥1𝑝𝑛1p,n\geq 1. We prove the claim by the induction on p𝑝p.

If p=0𝑝0p=0, then (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) is linked and the claim holds trivially. If there exist at least flink​(p−1,n)−1subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛1f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n)-1 edges z1​z2∈E​(H)subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2𝐸𝐻z_{1}z_{2}\in E(H) such that |β​(z1)∩β​(z2)|≤p−1𝛽subscript𝑧1𝛽subscript𝑧2𝑝1|\beta(z_{1})\cap\beta(z_{2})|\leq p-1, then (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) has a coarsening with adhesion at most p−1𝑝1p-1 and order at least flink​(p−1,n)subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n), and the claim follows by the induction hypothesis. Hence, assume that there are at most flink​(p−1,n)−2subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛2f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n)-2 such edges, and thus there exists a coarsening (H1,β1)subscript𝐻1subscript𝛽1(H_{1},\beta_{1}) of (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) of order flink​(p,n)−flink​(p−1,n)+2subscript𝑓link𝑝𝑛subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛2f_{\text{link}}(p,n)-f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n)+2 such that any two adjacent bags intersect in exactly p𝑝p vertices. If there exist at least flink​(p−1,n)−1subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛1f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n)-1 vertices z𝑧z of H1subscript𝐻1H_{1} with broken bags, then G𝐺G has a proper path decomposition with adhesion at most p−1𝑝1p-1 of order at least flink​(p−1,n)subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n), and the claim follows by induction. Otherwise, since (H1,β1)subscript𝐻1subscript𝛽1(H_{1},\beta_{1}) has order greater than (flink​(p−1,n)−2)​(n−1)subscript𝑓link𝑝1𝑛2𝑛1(f_{\text{link}}(p-1,n)-2)(n-1), it contains n𝑛n consecutive vertices with unbroken bags, and thus it has a coarsening of order n𝑛n in that no bag is broken. This coarsening is a proper linked path decomposition of G𝐺G. ∎

Lemma 27.

Let p≥0𝑝0p\geq 0 and n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 be integers. Every path decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) of a graph G𝐺G with adhesion at most p𝑝p of order at least np+1superscript𝑛𝑝1n^{p+1} has an appearance-universal coarsening of order n𝑛n.

Proof.

We prove the claim by the induction on p𝑝p. If p=0𝑝0p=0, then every vertex appears in exactly one bag and (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) is appearance-universal. If a vertex v𝑣v appears in at least npsuperscript𝑛𝑝n^{p} bags of the decomposition, then there exists a coarsening (H1,β1)subscript𝐻1subscript𝛽1(H_{1},\beta_{1}) of order npsuperscript𝑛𝑝n^{p} such that v𝑣v appears in all the bags. Let β1′​(z)=β​(z)∖{v}subscriptsuperscript𝛽′1𝑧𝛽𝑧𝑣\beta^{\prime}_{1}(z)=\beta(z)\setminus\{v\} for all z∈V​(H1)𝑧𝑉subscript𝐻1z\in V(H_{1}). Then (H1,β1′)subscript𝐻1subscriptsuperscript𝛽′1(H_{1},\beta^{\prime}_{1}) is a path decomposition of G−v𝐺𝑣G-v of adhesion at most p−1𝑝1p-1, and by the induction hypothesis, it has a coarsening (H2,β2′)subscript𝐻2subscriptsuperscript𝛽′2(H_{2},\beta^{\prime}_{2}) of order n𝑛n that is appearance-universal. Let β2​(z)=β​(z)∪{v}subscript𝛽2𝑧𝛽𝑧𝑣\beta_{2}(z)=\beta(z)\cup\{v\} for all z∈V​(H2)𝑧𝑉subscript𝐻2z\in V(H_{2}). Then (H2,β2)subscript𝐻2subscript𝛽2(H_{2},\beta_{2}) is an appearance-universal coarsening of (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) of order n𝑛n.

Hence, we can assume that every vertex appears in at most np−1superscript𝑛𝑝1n^{p}-1 bags of the decomposition. Let (H′,β′)superscript𝐻′superscript𝛽′(H^{\prime},\beta^{\prime}) be the coarsening obtained by dividing H𝐻H into subpaths with npsuperscript𝑛𝑝n^{p} vertices (plus possibly one shorter path at the end) and merging the bags in the subpaths. Then every vertex appears in at most two consecutive bags, and thus (H′,β′)superscript𝐻′superscript𝛽′(H^{\prime},\beta^{\prime}) is appearance-universal. ∎

Lemma 28.

Let n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 be an integer. Let S⊆V​(G)𝑆𝑉𝐺S\subseteq V(G). Every proper appearance-universal path decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) of order at least 3​n3𝑛3n has a coarsening of order n𝑛n with large interiors.

Proof.

Divide H𝐻H into subpaths with three vertices and merge the bags in each subpath, obtaining a coarsening (H1,β1)subscript𝐻1subscript𝛽1(H_{1},\beta_{1}) of order n𝑛n. We claim that this coarsening has large interiors.

Indeed, suppose that z0​z1​z2​z3​z4subscript𝑧0subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2subscript𝑧3subscript𝑧4z_{0}z_{1}z_{2}z_{3}z_{4} is a subpath of H𝐻H and consider a vertex z∈V​(H)𝑧𝑉𝐻z\in V(H) such that β1​(z)=β​(z1)∪β​(z2)∪β​(z3)subscript𝛽1𝑧𝛽subscript𝑧1𝛽subscript𝑧2𝛽subscript𝑧3\beta_{1}(z)=\beta(z_{1})\cup\beta(z_{2})\cup\beta(z_{3}). If a vertex v𝑣v belongs both to β​(z2)𝛽subscript𝑧2\beta(z_{2}) and β​(z0)𝛽subscript𝑧0\beta(z_{0}), then also v∈β1​(z1)𝑣subscript𝛽1subscript𝑧1v\in\beta_{1}(z_{1}), and since (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) is appearance-universal, it follows that v𝑣v belongs to all its bags. Similarly, any vertex in β​(z2)∩β​(z4)𝛽subscript𝑧2𝛽subscript𝑧4\beta(z_{2})\cap\beta(z_{4}) belongs to all bags. Since (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) is proper, some vertex of β​(z2)𝛽subscript𝑧2\beta(z_{2}) does not belong to all bags, and thus it is internal in (H1,β1)subscript𝐻1subscript𝛽1(H_{1},\beta_{1}).

Let z′superscript𝑧′z^{\prime} and z′′superscript𝑧′′z^{\prime\prime} be the neighbors of z𝑧z in H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}. Consider now an internal vertex v∈β1​(z)𝑣subscript𝛽1𝑧v\in\beta_{1}(z). Since v𝑣v is internal in (H1,β1)subscript𝐻1subscript𝛽1(H_{1},\beta_{1}), it does not appear in all bags of (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta), and by appearance-universality, v𝑣v appears in at most two consecutive bags of (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta). Consequently, v𝑣v does not appear in the bags of both z1subscript𝑧1z_{1} and z3subscript𝑧3z_{3}, and by symmetry, we can assume that v∉β​(z3)𝑣𝛽subscript𝑧3v\not\in\beta(z_{3}). Hence, any neighbor of v𝑣v in β​(z4)𝛽subscript𝑧4\beta(z_{4}) must belong to β​(z2)𝛽subscript𝑧2\beta(z_{2}), and by appearance-universality it must belong to all bags. It follows that v𝑣v does not have a neighbor both in β1​(z′)∖β1​(z′′)subscript𝛽1superscript𝑧′subscript𝛽1superscript𝑧′′\beta_{1}(z^{\prime})\setminus\beta_{1}(z^{\prime\prime}) and in β1​(z′′)∖β1​(z′)subscript𝛽1superscript𝑧′′subscript𝛽1superscript𝑧′\beta_{1}(z^{\prime\prime})\setminus\beta_{1}(z^{\prime}). ∎

A 444-tuple (F,M,l,r)𝐹𝑀𝑙𝑟(F,M,l,r), where F𝐹F is a graph, M𝑀M is a union of p𝑝p pairwise vertex-disjoint paths in F𝐹F, and l,r:[p]→V​(F):𝑙𝑟→delimited-[]𝑝𝑉𝐹l,r:[p]\to V(F) are injective functions such that for i=1,…,p𝑖1…𝑝i=1,\ldots,p, l​(i)𝑙𝑖l(i) and r​(i)𝑟𝑖r(i) are the two endpoints of one of the paths of M𝑀M, is called an extended bag of adhesion p𝑝p. Let (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) be a linked path decomposition of a graph G𝐺G. For each z∈V​(H)𝑧𝑉𝐻z\in V(H) with two neighbors x𝑥x and y𝑦y, fix a (β​(z)∩β​(x))−(β​(z)∩β​(y))𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑥𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑦(\beta(z)\cap\beta(x))-(\beta(z)\cap\beta(y)) linkage Lzsubscript𝐿𝑧L_{z} in G​[β​(z)]𝐺delimited-[]𝛽𝑧G[\beta(z)]. Let H0subscript𝐻0H_{0} be the path obtained from H𝐻H by removing its endpoints. Let L𝐿L be the union of the linkages Lzsubscript𝐿𝑧L_{z} over all z∈V​(H0)𝑧𝑉subscript𝐻0z\in V(H_{0}). Note that L𝐿L is the disjoint union of paths L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}, …, Lpsubscript𝐿𝑝L_{p}. Order the path H𝐻H arbitrarily, and let z𝑧z be a vertex of H0subscript𝐻0H_{0} whose predecessor in H𝐻H is x𝑥x and whose successor in H𝐻H is y𝑦y. Let lz:[p]→β​(z):subscript𝑙𝑧→delimited-[]𝑝𝛽𝑧l_{z}:[p]\to\beta(z) and rz:[p]→β​(z):subscript𝑟𝑧→delimited-[]𝑝𝛽𝑧r_{z}:[p]\to\beta(z) be functions defined so that lz​(i)subscript𝑙𝑧𝑖l_{z}(i) is the vertex of Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i} belonging to β​(z)∩β​(x)𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑥\beta(z)\cap\beta(x) and rz​(i)subscript𝑟𝑧𝑖r_{z}(i) is the vertex of Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i} belonging to β​(z)∩β​(y)𝛽𝑧𝛽𝑦\beta(z)\cap\beta(y). The 4-tuple Ez=(G​[β​(z)],Lz,lz,rz)subscript𝐸𝑧𝐺delimited-[]𝛽𝑧subscript𝐿𝑧subscript𝑙𝑧subscript𝑟𝑧E_{z}=(G[\beta(z)],L_{z},l_{z},r_{z}) is the extended bag of z𝑧z. A finite extended bag property is a function that to each extended bag of adhesion p𝑝p assigns an element of a finite set Xpsubscript𝑋𝑝X_{p}. By the pigeonhole principle, we have the following.

Observation 29.

For all integers p≥0𝑝0p\geq 0 and n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 and for any finite extended bag property π𝜋\pi, there exists an integer N𝑁N as follows. For any linked decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) of adhesion at most p𝑝p and any Z⊆V​(H)𝑍𝑉𝐻Z\subseteq V(H) such that |Z|≥N𝑍𝑁|Z|\geq N, there exists a set U⊆Z𝑈𝑍U\subseteq Z of size n𝑛n such that π​(Ex)=π​(Ey)𝜋subscript𝐸𝑥𝜋subscript𝐸𝑦\pi(E_{x})=\pi(E_{y}) for all x,y∈U𝑥𝑦𝑈x,y\in U.

We are now ready to start working towards the proof of Theorem 17. Let us start with a lemma that enables us to obtain many t𝑡t-islands separated from the rest of the graph by small cuts.

Lemma 30.

For all integers p≥0𝑝0p\geq 0 and t,m,l≥1𝑡𝑚𝑙1t,m,l\geq 1, there exists an integer N≥1𝑁1N\geq 1 as follows. Let (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) be a linked path decomposition of a graph G𝐺G, with large interiors, adhesion at most p𝑝p and order at least N𝑁N. Then either G𝐺G contains Kt,msubscript𝐾𝑡𝑚K_{t,m} or It−1+Pmsubscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚I_{t-1}+P_{m} as a minor, or there exists a subpath H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime} of H𝐻H of length l𝑙l such that the internal vertices of the bag of z𝑧z form a t𝑡t-island in G𝐺G for every z∈V​(H′)𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′z\in V(H^{\prime}).

Proof.

Suppose that there does not exist a subpath H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime} of H𝐻H as above. Consider any vertex z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z of degree two, and let (G​[β​(z)],Lz,lz,rz)𝐺delimited-[]𝛽𝑧subscript𝐿𝑧subscript𝑙𝑧subscript𝑟𝑧(G[\beta(z)],L_{z},l_{z},r_{z}) be its extended bag. Choose t𝑡t of the non-internal neighbors v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}, …, vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}, and let π​(z)=(σ1,…,σt,σz)𝜋𝑧subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑡subscript𝜎𝑧\pi(z)=(\sigma_{1},\ldots,\sigma_{t},\sigma_{z}), where for i=1,…,t𝑖1…𝑡i=1,\ldots,t, we have σi=jsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗\sigma_{i}=j if vi=lz​(j)subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑙𝑧𝑗v_{i}=l_{z}(j) or vi=rz​(j)subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑟𝑧𝑗v_{i}=r_{z}(j), and σz=jsubscript𝜎𝑧𝑗\sigma_{z}=j if z𝑧z lies on the path in Lzsubscript𝐿𝑧L_{z} with ends lz​(j)subscript𝑙𝑧𝑗l_{z}(j) and rz​(j)subscript𝑟𝑧𝑗r_{z}(j), and σz=0subscript𝜎𝑧0\sigma_{z}=0 otherwise. Observe that σ1subscript𝜎1\sigma_{1}, …, σtsubscript𝜎𝑡\sigma_{t} are distinct, since H𝐻H has large interiors. Note that π𝜋\pi is a finite extended bag property, and by Observation 29, we can assume that there exist distinct vertices z1subscript𝑧1z_{1}, …, zmsubscript𝑧𝑚z_{m} in V​(H)∖Z𝑉𝐻𝑍V(H)\setminus Z of degree two such that π​(z1)=π​(z2)=…=π​(zm)𝜋subscript𝑧1𝜋subscript𝑧2…𝜋subscript𝑧𝑚\pi(z_{1})=\pi(z_{2})=\ldots=\pi(z_{m}). Without loss of generality, we can assume that π​(z1)=(1,2,…,t,a)𝜋subscript𝑧112…𝑡𝑎\pi(z_{1})=(1,2,\ldots,t,a), where a∈{0,1,t+1}𝑎01𝑡1a\in\{0,1,t+1\}. Let L𝐿L be the union of the linkages Lzsubscript𝐿𝑧L_{z} over all vertices z∈V​(H)𝑧𝑉𝐻z\in V(H) of degree two, and let L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}, …, Lpsubscript𝐿𝑝L_{p} be the paths of L𝐿L.

If a∈{0,t+1}𝑎0𝑡1a\in\{0,t+1\}, then contract each of the paths L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}, …, Ltsubscript𝐿𝑡L_{t} to a single vertex x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}, …, xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}; since vz1subscript𝑣subscript𝑧1v_{z_{1}}, …, vzmsubscript𝑣subscript𝑧𝑚v_{z_{m}} are adjacent to all of x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}, …, xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}, we obtain Kt,msubscript𝐾𝑡𝑚K_{t,m} as a minor of G𝐺G.

If a=1𝑎1a=1, then contract each of the paths L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}, …, Ltsubscript𝐿𝑡L_{t} to a single vertex x2subscript𝑥2x_{2}, …, xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}, and contract the parts of the path L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} between vertices vz1subscript𝑣subscript𝑧1v_{z_{1}}, …, vzmsubscript𝑣subscript𝑧𝑚v_{z_{m}} so that they form a path on m𝑚m vertices. We obtain It−1+Pmsubscript𝐼𝑡1subscript𝑃𝑚I_{t-1}+P_{m} as a minor of G𝐺G. ∎

We utilize Lemma 30 in an inductive argument as follows.

Lemma 31.

For all integers k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0 and m,t≥1𝑚𝑡1m,t\geq 1, there exist real ε,C>0𝜀𝐶0\varepsilon,C>0 as follows. Let G𝐺G be a graph with at least C𝐶C vertices, and let S⊆V​(G)𝑆𝑉𝐺S\subseteq V(G) be such that |S|≤ε​|V​(G)|+2​k+3𝑆𝜀𝑉𝐺2𝑘3|S|\leq\varepsilon|V(G)|+2k+3. Proof.

Let n4subscript𝑛4n_{4} be chosen so that Lemma 30 holds for p=k+1𝑝𝑘1p=k+1, t𝑡t, m𝑚m, l=4​k+6𝑙4𝑘6l=4k+6 and N=n4𝑁subscript𝑛4N=n_{4}. Let n3=3​n4subscript𝑛33subscript𝑛4n_{3}=3n_{4}, n2=n3k+2subscript𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑛3𝑘2n_{2}=n_{3}^{k+2}, n1=flink​(k+1,n2)subscript𝑛1subscript𝑓link𝑘1subscript𝑛2n_{1}=f_{\text{link}}(k+1,n_{2}), and C=(k+1)​n1n1𝐶𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛1C=(k+1)n_{1}^{n_{1}}, and ε=1(2​k+3)​C𝜀12𝑘3𝐶\varepsilon=\frac{1}{(2k+3)C}.

We prove that the lemma holds for these values of ε𝜀\varepsilon and C𝐶C by induction on the number of vertices of G𝐺G. Suppose that G𝐺G has a separation (G1,G2)subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2(G_{1},G_{2}) of order at most (k+1)𝑘1(k+1) such that |V​(Gi)|≥C𝑉subscript𝐺𝑖𝐶|V(G_{i})|\geq C for i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2. Let Si=(S∩V​(Gi))∪(V​(G1)∩V​(G2))subscript𝑆𝑖𝑆𝑉subscript𝐺𝑖𝑉subscript𝐺1𝑉subscript𝐺2S_{i}=(S\cap V(G_{i}))\cup(V(G_{1})\cap V(G_{2})) for i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2. If |Si|≤ϵ​|V​(Gi)|+2​k+3subscript𝑆𝑖italic-ϵ𝑉subscript𝐺𝑖2𝑘3|S_{i}|\leq\epsilon|V(G_{i})|+2k+3 for some i∈{1,2}𝑖12i\in\{1,2\} then the lemma holds by the induction hypothesis applied to Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}. Otherwise, we have

|S|≥|S1|+|S2|−2​(k+1)≥ε​|V​(G)​|+2​(2​k+3)−2​(k+1)>​ε|​V​(G)|+2​k+3,𝑆subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆22𝑘1conditional𝜀𝑉𝐺ket22𝑘32𝑘1𝜀𝑉𝐺2𝑘3|S|\geq|S_{1}|+|S_{2}|-2(k+1)\geq\varepsilon|V(G)|+2(2k+3)-2(k+1)>\varepsilon|V(G)|+2k+3,

a contradiction. Thus we assume that no separation as above exists.

The graph G𝐺G has a proper tree decomposition (T,β)𝑇𝛽(T,\beta) with bags of size at most k+1𝑘1k+1. Clearly, the decomposition has order at least |V​(G)|/(k+1)≥C/(k+1)=n1n1𝑉𝐺𝑘1𝐶𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛1|V(G)|/(k+1)\geq C/(k+1)=n_{1}^{n_{1}}. Hence, by Lemma 25, G𝐺G has a proper path decomposition of adhesion at most k+1𝑘1k+1 and order n1subscript𝑛1n_{1}. By Lemma 26, G𝐺G has a proper linked path decomposition of adhesion at most k+1𝑘1k+1 and order n2subscript𝑛2n_{2}. By Lemma 27, this decomposition has an appearance-universal coarsening of order n3subscript𝑛3n_{3}, and by Lemma 28, this decomposition can be further coarsened to a decomposition (H,β)𝐻𝛽(H,\beta) of order n4subscript𝑛4n_{4} with large interiors. By Lemma 30, there exists a subpath H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime} of H𝐻H of length l𝑙l such that the set internal vertices Izsubscript𝐼𝑧I_{z} of the bag of z𝑧z form a t𝑡t-island in G𝐺G for every z∈V​(H′)𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′z\in V(H^{\prime}). If Iz∩S=∅subscript𝐼𝑧𝑆I_{z}\cap S=\emptyset for some z∈V​(H′)𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′z\in V(H^{\prime}) then Izsubscript𝐼𝑧I_{z} is the required t𝑡t-island, and so we assume Iz∩S≠∅subscript𝐼𝑧𝑆I_{z}\cap S\neq\emptyset for every such z𝑧z. In particular, |S|≥4​k+6𝑆4𝑘6|S|\geq 4k+6, and thus |V​(G)|≥(|S|−2​k−3)/ε≥(2​k+3)/ε≥(2​k+3)2​C𝑉𝐺𝑆2𝑘3𝜀2𝑘3𝜀superscript2𝑘32𝐶|V(G)|\geq(|S|-2k-3)/\varepsilon\geq(2k+3)/\varepsilon\geq(2k+3)^{2}C.

Note that by our earlier assumption on the existence of certain separations, we have that |β​(z)|≥C𝛽𝑧𝐶|\beta(z)|\geq C for at most one z∈V​(H′)𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′z\in V(H^{\prime}), and therefore we can select a subpath H′′superscript𝐻′′H^{\prime\prime} of H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime} of length l/2=2​k+3𝑙22𝑘3l/2=2k+3 such that |β​(z)|<C𝛽𝑧𝐶|\beta(z)|<C for every z∈V​(H′′)𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′′z\in V(H^{\prime\prime}). Let X=⋃z∈V​(H′′)β​(z)𝑋subscript𝑧𝑉superscript𝐻′′𝛽𝑧X=\bigcup_{z\in V(H^{\prime\prime})}\beta(z) and Y=⋃z∈V​(H)−V​(H′′)β​(z)𝑌subscript𝑧𝑉𝐻𝑉superscript𝐻′′𝛽𝑧Y=\bigcup_{z\in V(H)-V(H^{\prime\prime})}\beta(z). Then |X∩Y|≤2​k+2𝑋𝑌2𝑘2|X\cap Y|\leq 2k+2, |X|≤(2​k+3)​C𝑋2𝑘3𝐶|X|\leq(2k+3)C, and |S∩(X∖Y)|≥2​k+3𝑆𝑋𝑌2𝑘3|S\cap(X\setminus Y)|\geq 2k+3 by our assumptions. Let G′=G​[Y]superscript𝐺′𝐺delimited-[]𝑌G^{\prime}=G[Y] and S′=(S∩Y)∪(X∩Y)superscript𝑆′𝑆𝑌𝑋𝑌S^{\prime}=(S\cap Y)\cup(X\cap Y). We have

|S′|superscript𝑆′\displaystyle|S^{\prime}| ≤|S|−1=|S|−ε​(2​k+3)​C≤|S|−ε​|X|absent𝑆1𝑆𝜀2𝑘3𝐶𝑆𝜀𝑋\displaystyle\leq|S|-1=|S|-\varepsilon(2k+3)C\leq|S|-\varepsilon|X|
≤ε​|V​(G)|+2​k+3−ε​|X|≤ε​|V​(G′)|+2​k+3.absent𝜀𝑉𝐺2𝑘3𝜀𝑋𝜀𝑉superscript𝐺′2𝑘3\displaystyle\leq\varepsilon|V(G)|+2k+3-\varepsilon|X|\leq\varepsilon|V(G^{\prime})|+2k+3.

Since |V​(G)|≥(2​k+3)2​C𝑉𝐺superscript2𝑘32𝐶|V(G)|\geq(2k+3)^{2}C, we have |V​(G′)|≥|V​(G)|−|X|≥(2​k+3)​(2​k+2)​C>C𝑉superscript𝐺′𝑉𝐺𝑋2𝑘32𝑘2𝐶𝐶|V(G^{\prime})|\geq|V(G)|-|X|\geq(2k+3)(2k+2)C>C. By the induction hypothesis, G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} contains a t𝑡t-island I𝐼I disjoint from S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}. Clearly, I𝐼I is a t𝑡t-island in G𝐺G disjoint from S𝑆S, as desired. ∎

The main result now readily follows.

Proof of Theorem 17.

By Theorem 16 we have pcol⋆​(𝒢)=p​(𝒢)subscriptpcol⋆𝒢𝑝𝒢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})=p({\cal G}). By Observation 3 we have pcol⋆​(𝒢)≥col⋆​(𝒢)≥tsubscriptpcol⋆𝒢subscriptcol⋆𝒢𝑡\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})\geq\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})\geq t. Finally, by Lemma 31 we have p​(𝒢)≤t𝑝𝒢𝑡p({\cal G})\leq t (if G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in{\cal G} has less than C𝐶C vertices, then G𝐺G is 1/C1𝐶1/C-resistant to t𝑡t-percolation for every t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1). ∎

5 Concluding remarks

In this paper we studied improper colorings of minor-closed graph classes, where we used the size of the maximum monochromatic component as a measure of impropriety. One can attempt building a similar theory for other impropriety measures as follows. We say that a graph parameter f𝑓f with values in ℝ+∪{+∞}subscriptℝ\mathbb{R}_{+}\cup\{+\infty\} is connected if for a disconnected graph G𝐺G with components G1,G2,…,Gksubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2…subscript𝐺𝑘G_{1},G_{2},\ldots,G_{k} we have f​(G)=max1≤i≤k⁡f​(Gi)𝑓𝐺subscript1𝑖𝑘𝑓subscript𝐺𝑖f(G)=\max_{1\leq i\leq k}f(G_{i}).

Let f𝑓f be a connected monotone graph parameter. The f𝑓f-chromatic number χf​(𝒢)subscript𝜒𝑓𝒢\chi_{f}({\cal G}) of a graph class G𝐺G as the minimum t𝑡t such that there exists real C𝐶C satisfying the following. For every G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G} there exists a partition V1,…,Vtsubscript𝑉1…subscript𝑉𝑡V_{1},\ldots,V_{t} of V​(G)𝑉𝐺V(G) so that f​(G​[Vi])≤C𝑓𝐺delimited-[]subscript𝑉𝑖𝐶f(G[V_{i}])\leq C for every 1≤i≤t1𝑖𝑡1\leq i\leq t. For example, Theorem 9 implies that χtw​(𝒢)≤2subscript𝜒tw𝒢2\chi_{\operatorname{tw}}({\cal G})\leq 2 for every minor-closed class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}.

One can also define the f𝑓f-list chromatic number χfl​(𝒢)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝑓𝒢\chi^{l}_{f}({\cal G}) and the f𝑓f-coloring number colf​(𝒢)subscriptcol𝑓𝒢\text{col}_{f}({\cal G}) of a graph class G𝐺G analogously to the clustered list chromatic and coloring numbers. The inequalities colf​(𝒢)≥χfl​(𝒢)≥χf​(𝒢)subscriptcol𝑓𝒢subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝑓𝒢subscript𝜒𝑓𝒢\text{col}_{f}(\mathcal{G})\geq\chi^{l}_{f}(\mathcal{G})\geq\chi_{f}(\mathcal{G}) hold for any choice of f𝑓f.

Note that considering f𝑓f to be a connected graph parameter defined by f​(G)=1𝑓𝐺1f(G)=1, if G𝐺G is edgeless, and f=+∞𝑓f=+\infty, otherwise, one recovers from the definitions above the ordinary chromatic, list-chromatic numbers, and the coloring number.

The graph parameter ΔΔ\Delta (maximum degree) is particularly well-studied in this context. Edwards et al. [10] have shown that χΔ​(𝒳​(Kt))=t−1subscript𝜒Δ𝒳subscript𝐾𝑡𝑡1\chi_{\Delta}(\mathcal{X}(K_{t}))=t-1. Ossona de Mendez, Oum and Wood [6] characterized minor closed graph classes with given ΔΔ\Delta-list chromatic number as follows.

Theorem 32.

A minor-closed class of graphs 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} satisfies χΔl​(𝒢)≤tsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙Δ𝒢𝑡\chi^{l}_{\Delta}({\cal G})\leq t if and only if there exists m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 such that Kt,m∉𝒢subscript𝐾𝑡𝑚𝒢K_{t,m}\not\in{\cal G}.

As we mentioned before, Conjecture 4 implies that col⋆​(𝒢)=χ⋆l​(𝒢)subscriptcol⋆𝒢subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙⋆𝒢\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})=\chi^{l}_{\star}({\cal G}) for every minor-closed class 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. Analogously, Theorem 32 and Conjecture 4 imply that

χΔl​(𝒢)≤colΔ​(𝒢)≤col⋆​(𝒢)≤χΔl​(𝒢)+1.subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙Δ𝒢subscriptcolΔ𝒢subscriptcol⋆𝒢subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙Δ𝒢1\chi^{l}_{\Delta}({\cal G})\leq\text{col}_{\Delta}({\cal G})\leq\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G})\leq\chi^{l}_{\Delta}({\cal G})+1.

Unfortunately, the left inequality does not always holds with equality, as shown in the next lemma.

Lemma 33.

Let 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} be the class of outerplanar graphs. Then χΔl​(𝒪)=2subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙Δ𝒪2\chi^{l}_{\Delta}(\mathcal{O})=2 and colΔ​(𝒪)=3subscriptcolΔ𝒪3\text{col}_{\Delta}(\mathcal{O})=3.

Proof.

We have χΔl​(𝒪)=2subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙Δ𝒪2\chi^{l}_{\Delta}(\mathcal{O})=2 by Theorem 32. The treewidth of graphs in 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} is at most 222 and K2,3∉𝒪subscript𝐾23𝒪K_{2,3}\not\in\mathcal{O}. Thus it follows from Theorem 7 that col⋆​(𝒪)≤3subscriptcol⋆𝒪3\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{O})\leq 3, and therefore colΔ​(𝒪)≤3subscriptcolΔ𝒪3\text{col}_{\Delta}(\mathcal{O})\leq 3.

It remains to show that col⋆​(𝒪)≥3subscriptcol⋆𝒪3\text{col}_{\star}(\mathcal{O})\geq 3 , i.e. for every C>0𝐶0C>0 there exists an outerplanar graph G𝐺G such that G𝐺G contains no 222-island S𝑆S such that Δ​(G​[S])≤CΔ𝐺delimited-[]𝑆𝐶\Delta(G[S])\leq C. Indeed, consider an outerplanar graph constructed as follows. Let P1,P2subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1},P_{2} and P3subscript𝑃3P_{3} be three vertex-disjoint paths on C+1𝐶1C+1 vertices. Let visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} be an end of Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} for i=1,2,3𝑖123i=1,2,3. The graph G𝐺G is obtained from P1∪P2∪P3subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3P_{1}\cup P_{2}\cup P_{3} by joining visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} by an edge to every vertex of Pi+1subscript𝑃𝑖1P_{i+1} for i=1,2,3𝑖123i=1,2,3, where P4=P1subscript𝑃4subscript𝑃1P_{4}=P_{1} by convention. Let S𝑆S be a 222-island in G𝐺G. Suppose that v1,v2,v3∉Ssubscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2subscript𝑣3𝑆v_{1},v_{2},v_{3}\not\in S. Then without loss of generality there exists a vertex in v∈V​(P2)∩S𝑣𝑉subscript𝑃2𝑆v\in V(P_{2})\cap S. Choose such a vertex v𝑣v closest to v2subscript𝑣2v_{2} along P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}. Then v𝑣v has two neighbors not in S𝑆S: one along P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} and v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}. This contradiction implies that vi∈Ssubscript𝑣𝑖𝑆v_{i}\in S for some i∈{1,2,3}𝑖123i\in\{1,2,3\}. As visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} has degree C+2𝐶2C+2, at least C+1𝐶1C+1 of its neighbors lie in S𝑆S, implying Δ​(G​[S])>CΔ𝐺delimited-[]𝑆𝐶\Delta(G[S])>C, as desired. ∎

Following this line of inquiry one might ask how closely colf​(𝒢)subscriptcol𝑓𝒢\text{col}_{f}({\cal G}) and χfl​(𝒢)subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝑓𝒢\chi^{l}_{f}({\cal G}) are related for other (natural) connected graph parameters f𝑓f. Dvořák, Pekárek, and Sereni [9] study this question in more detail.
